article.description:
Chevon Troutman scored 18 points and
Pittsburgh showed off a new look offensively in beating Howard
81-55 Saturday night in the Panthers' opener.
article.headline: Pittsburgh shows new offensive look in victory
article.linkText: Howard's end: No. 17 Pitt is too tough
article.story: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Freshman guard Ronald Ramon made his first career 3-pointer only 2 minutes and 55 seconds into No. 17 Pittsburgh's season opener. It could prove to be a significant moment not only for him, but for his team. Chevon Troutman, Pittsburgh's only senior starter, had 18 points and 11 rebounds while the Panthers showed off a new look offensively in beating Howard 81-55 Saturday night. The 6-foot-7 Troutman outmuscled the smaller Bison along the baseline for short-range shots and putbacks to help the Panthers power to leads of 11-0 and 30-8 en route to a 40-15 halftime lead. Pittsburgh started three regulars from last season's 31-win team, but it was Ramon who added a different twist to a team that relied on a physical defense while making three successive trips to the NCAA round of 16. He quickly hit three 3-pointers against a pulled-back Howard defense. Ramon, the first freshman to start a Pitt opener since Ricardo Greer in 1997, was 4-of-6 as Pitt made 6 of 12 3-point attempts -- 5 of 8 in the first half. Pitt finished 320th in 3-point shooting among the 326 Division I teams last season, making just 30.6 percent of its shots beyond the arc. Ramon couldn't help but notice Pitt's terrible outside shooting and almost couldn't wait to step on campus. "I knew I could come in and help this team with my shooting, so I just did what I expected I could do," Ramon said. The Panthers' lack of reliable outside shooting was especially evident when they averaged only 53.6 points in their three NCAA tournament games, a weakness that more than offset their No. 2-ranked defense. "I've been doing it since high school," said Ramon, whose scored his 12 points on 3-pointers. "I just went out and played like it was a practice. There was no pressure, just go out and play." Ramon's father, Ricardo, played pro basketball in the Dominican Republic, Brazil and Argentina and began working with his son on his outside shooting when he was only a youngster. Still, Ramon wasn't considered a major recruiting coup for Pitt despite averaging 24 points at All Hallows High in the Bronx last season. "We think we've found a very good player who may have been overlooked by some people," coach Jamie Dixon said. Thanks to his team's early dominance, Dixon didn't wait until the second half to empty his bench, with 10 players scoring by halftime and 11 scoring overall. Chris Taft also scored 12 points and junior college transfer John DeGroat added 11 points and seven rebounds as Pitt outrebounded Howard 55-26. "We were playing at times with four new guys out there," Dixon said. "It's a young team. We haven't had a team this young in a number of years." Howard (0-2), one of the nation's worst Division I teams last season with a 6-22 record, scored only two points in the opening 10:17. Cliffone Ault was the only Bison player with more than two points until well into the second half. He finished with 24 for Howard, which was coming off a 74-63 loss Friday night at St. Francis, Pa. "Pitt was too strong, but we knew what we were getting into," Howard coach Frankie Allen said. "Ramon is an outstanding outside shooter and really complements their inside game." Pittsburgh, a nation's-best 88-16 the previous three seasons, won its 16th in a row against a non-conference opponent and its 41st in a row at home against a non-Big East opponent. The Panthers are 36-1 at home since the Petersen Events Center opened two years ago. Pitt hasn't lost a season opener since falling to Illinois State 69-50 in 1996.

statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
